020import static org.apiguardian.api.API.Status.STABLE;

022import java.io.InputStream;
023import java.io.Reader;
024import java.math.BigDecimal;
025import java.net.URL;
026import java.sql.Array;
027import java.sql.BatchUpdateException;
028import java.sql.Blob;
029import java.sql.Clob;
030import java.sql.Connection;
031import java.sql.Date;
032import java.sql.JDBCType;
033import java.sql.NClob;
034import java.sql.Ref;
035import java.sql.ResultSet;
036import java.sql.ResultSetMetaData;
037import java.sql.RowId;
038import java.sql.SQLException;
039import java.sql.SQLFeatureNotSupportedException;
040import java.sql.SQLOutput;
041import java.sql.SQLTimeoutException;
042import java.sql.SQLType;
043import java.sql.SQLWarning;
044import java.sql.SQLXML;
045import java.sql.Time;
046import java.sql.Timestamp;
047import java.util.Calendar;
048import java.util.List;

051import org.apiguardian.api.API;
052import org.tquadrat.foundation.annotation.ClassVersion;
053import org.tquadrat.foundation.sql.internal.EnhancedPreparedStatementImpl;

055/**
056 *  <p>{@summary The definition of an enhanced
057 *  {@link java.sql.PreparedStatement}.}</p>
058 *  <p>The implementation of this interface wraps an instance of
059 *  {@code PreparedStatement} and provides solutions for three issues that the
060 *  original definition has:</p>
061 *  <ol>
062 *    <li>The placeholders in a prepared statement are only identified by their
063 *    position, and it is quite easy to mix those positions up, especially when
064 *    modifying the statement. This can cause errors during runtime that are
065 *    very difficult to detect.</li>
066 *    <li>The fact that the placeholders are only position based causes another
067 *    inconvenience. Assume an SQL statement like that one below:
068 *    <pre><code>    SELECT *
069 *    FROM table1,table2
070 *    WHERE table1.key = table2.key
071 *          AND table1.value &lt; ?
072 *          AND table2.value &gt; ?</code></pre>
073 *    where the question mark stands for the same value. This would require to
074 *    call
075 *    {@link java.sql.PreparedStatement#setInt(int, int) setInt()}
076 *    twice, with the same value, but a different position index.</li>
077 *    <li>{@code PreparedStatement} does not allow to log the SQL statement
078 *    together with the assigned values for the placeholders; at least this is
079 *    not defined in the interface itself; some vendor specific implementations
080 *    may provide such an additional API, but there is no generic one. An
081 *    implementation of this interface takes a method that can write any
082 *    executed SQL statement to a logger.</li>
083 *  </ol>
084 *
085 *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
086 *  @version $Id: EnhancedPreparedStatement.java 1022 2022-03-03 23:03:40Z tquadrat $
087 *  @since 0.1.0
088 *
089 *  @UMLGraph.link
090 *
091 *  @see    java.sql.PreparedStatement
092 */
093@SuppressWarnings( {"ClassWithTooManyMethods", "OverlyComplexClass"} )
094@ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: EnhancedPreparedStatement.java 1022 2022-03-03 23:03:40Z tquadrat $" )
095@API( status = STABLE, since = "0.1.0" )
096public sealed interface EnhancedPreparedStatement extends AutoCloseable
097    permits org.tquadrat.foundation.sql.internal.EnhancedPreparedStatementBase
098{
099        /*---------------*\
100    ====** Inner Classes **====================================================
101        \*---------------*/
102    /**
103     *  <p>{@summary The definition of logger method for a
104     *  {@link java.sql.PreparedStatement}.}</p>
105     *  <p>This is a functional interface whose functional method is
106     *  {@link #log(String,String,List,StackTraceElement[])}.</p>
107     *
108     *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
109     *  @version $Id: EnhancedPreparedStatement.java 1022 2022-03-03 23:03:40Z tquadrat $
110     *  @since 0.1.0
111     *
112     *  @UMLGraph.link
113     *
114     *  @see    java.sql.PreparedStatement
115     */
116    @SuppressWarnings( "InnerClassOfInterface" )
117    @ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: EnhancedPreparedStatement.java 1022 2022-03-03 23:03:40Z tquadrat $" )
118    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.1.0" )
119    @FunctionalInterface
120    public interface StatementLogger
121    {
122        /**
123         *  Provides the logging information.
124         *
125         *  @param  operation   The name of the operation that logs.
126         *  @param  statement   The source of the prepared statement.
127         *  @param  values  The values.
128         *  @param  stackTrace  The stacktrace; can be {@code null}.
129         */
130        @SuppressWarnings( "MethodCanBeVariableArityMethod" )
131        public void log( final String operation, final String statement, final List<String> values, final StackTraceElement [] stackTrace );
132    }
133    //  interface StatementLogger
134
135        /*-----------*\
136    ====** Constants **========================================================
137        \*-----------*/
138    /**
139     *  The regular expression that is used to identify a named parameter in
140     *  the SQL statement text: {@value}.
141     *
142     *  @see    #prepareStatement(Connection,String)
143     */
144    public static final String VARIABLE_PATTERN = "[^:](:[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*)";
145
146        /*---------*\
147    ====** Methods **==========================================================
148        \*---------*/
149    /**
150     *  Adds a set of parameters to this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
151     *  instance's batch of commands.
152     *
153     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
154     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
155     *
156     *  @see    java.sql.Statement#addBatch(String)
157     */
158    public void addBatch() throws SQLException;
159
160    /**
161     *  <p>{@summary Cancels this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} object if
162     *  both the DBMS and driver support aborting an SQL statement.}</p>
163     *  <p>This method can be used by one thread to cancel a statement that
164     *  is being executed by another thread.</p>
165     *
166     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
167     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
168     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
169     *      support this method.
170     */
171    void cancel() throws SQLException;
172
173    /**
174     *  Empties this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance's current list
175     *  of SQL commands.
176     *
177     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
178     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}, or the
179     *      driver does not support batch updates.
180     *
181     *  @see    #addBatch()
182     *  @see    java.sql.DatabaseMetaData#supportsBatchUpdates()
183     */
184    public void clearBatch() throws SQLException;
185
186    /**
187     *  <p>{@summary Clears the current parameter values immediately.}</p>
188     *  <p>In general, parameter values remain in force for repeated use of a
189     *  statement. Setting a parameter value automatically clears its previous
190     *  value. However, in some cases it is useful to immediately release the
191     *  resources used by the current parameter values; this can be done by
192     *  calling the method {@code clearParameters()}.
193     *
194     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
195     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
196     */
197    public void clearParameters() throws SQLException;
198
199    /**
200     *  <p>{@summary Clears all the warnings reported on this
201     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.} After a call to this
202     *  method, the method
203     *  {@link #getWarnings()}
204     *  will return {@code null} until a new warning is reported for this
205     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.</p>
206     *
207     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
208     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
209     */
210    public void clearWarnings() throws SQLException;
211
212    /**
213     *  <p>{@summary Releases this instance's database and JDBC resources
214     *  immediately instead of waiting for this to happen when it is
215     *  automatically closed.} It is generally good practice to release
216     *  resources as soon as you are finished with them to avoid tying up
217     *  database resources.</p>
218     *  <p>Calling the method {@code close} on a
219     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} object that is already closed has no
220     *  effect.</p>
221     *
222     *  @note   When a {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance is closed,
223     *      its current {@code ResultSet} instance, if one exists, is also
224     *      closed.
225     *
226     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred.
227     */
228    @Override
229    public void close() throws SQLException;
230
231    /**
232     *  <p>{@summary Specifies that this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} will
233     *  be closed when all its dependent result sets are closed.} If the
234     *  execution of the {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} does not produce
235     *  any result sets, this method has no effect.</p>
236     *
237     *  @note   Multiple calls to {@code closeOnCompletion()} do not toggle the
238     *      effect on this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}. However, a call
239     *      to {@code closeOnCompletion()} does affect both the subsequent
240     *      execution of statements, and statements that currently have open,
241     *      dependent, result sets.
242     *
243     *  @throws SQLException    This method was called on a closed
244     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
245     */
246    public void closeOnCompletion() throws SQLException;
247
248    /**
249     *  <p>{@summary Enables the logging output for the
250     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instances.}</p>
251     *  <p>The {@code logger} method takes three arguments:</p>
252     *  <ol>
253     *      <li>{@code operation} â The name of the operation that logs.</li>
254     *      <li>{@code statement} â The source of the prepared statement.</li>
255     *      <li>{@code values} â A list of the values in the format
256     *      <pre><code>&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;<b> [</b>&lt;<i>type</i>&gt;<b>]:&lt;<i>value</i>&gt;</b></code></pre>
257     *      A type of {@code NULL} indicates an unknown type; for large values (like
258     *      {@link java.sql.Blob}
259     *      or
260     *      {@link java.io.Reader})
261     *      only the class is given instead of the real value.</li>
262     *      <li>{@code stacktrace} â The stacktrace; will be {@code null} if
263     *      {@code addStacktrace} is {@code false}.</li>
264     *  </ol>
265     *  <p>The {@code logCheck} method returns {@code true} only when logging
266     *  should be done. No information is collected while it returns
267     *  {@code false}. As the method is called for nearly any operation, its
268     *  implementation should be as efficient as possible.</p>
269     *
270     *  @param  logger  The method that takes the logging information.
271     *  @param  logCheck    The method that returns a flag whether log output
272     *      is desired.
273     *  @param  addStacktrace   {@code true} if the stacktrace should be added
274     *      to the log output.
275     */
276    public static void enableLogging( final StatementLogger logger, final BooleanSupplier logCheck, final boolean addStacktrace )
277    {
278        EnhancedPreparedStatementImpl.enableLogging( logger, logCheck, addStacktrace );
279    }   //  enableLogging()
280
281    /**
282     *  <p>{@summary Returns a SQL identifier.} If {@code identifier} is a
283     *  simple SQL identifier:</p>
284     *  <ul>
285     *      <li>Return the original value if {@code alwaysQuote} is
286     *      {@code false}</li>
287     *      <li>Return a delimited identifier if {@code alwaysQuote} is
288     *      {@code true}</li>
289     *  </ul>
290     *  <p>If {@code identifier} is not a simple SQL identifier,
291     *  {@code identifier} will be enclosed in double quotes if not already
292     *  present. If the datasource does not support double quotes for delimited
293     *  identifiers, the identifier should be enclosed by the string returned
294     *  from
295     *  {@link java.sql.DatabaseMetaData#getIdentifierQuoteString}.
296     *  If the datasource does not support delimited identifiers, a
297     *  {@code SQLFeatureNotSupportedException} should be thrown.</p>
298     *  <p>A {@code SQLException} will be thrown if {@code identifier} contains
299     *  any characters invalid in a delimited identifier or the identifier
300     *  length is invalid for the datasource.</p>
301     *
302     *  @param  identifier  An SQL identifier.
303     *  @param  alwaysQuote Indicates if a simple SQL identifier should be
304     *      returned as a quoted identifier.
305     *  @return A simple SQL identifier or a delimited identifier
306     *  @throws SQLException    The identifier was not a valid identifier.
307     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The datasource does not support
308     *      delimited identifiers.
309     *  @throws NullPointerException    The identifier was {@code null}.
310     */
311    public String enquoteIdentifier(String identifier, boolean alwaysQuote) throws SQLException;
312
313
314    /**
315     *  <p>{@summary Returns a {@code String} enclosed in single quotes.} Any
316     *  occurrence of a single quote within the string will be replaced by two
317     *  single quotes.</p>
318     *
319     *  <blockquote>
320     *      <table class="striped">
321     *          <caption>Examples of the conversion:</caption>
322     *          <thead>
323     *              <tr>
324     *                  <th scope="col">Value</th>
325     *                  <th scope="col">Result</th>
326     *              </tr>
327     *          </thead>
328     *          <tbody style="text-align:center">
329     *              <tr>
330     *                  <th scope="row">Hello</th>
331     *                  <td>'Hello'</td>
332     *              </tr>
333     *              <tr>
334     *                  <th scope="row">G'Day</th>
335     *                  <td>'G''Day'</td>
336     *              </tr>
337     *              <tr>
338     *                  <th scope="row">'G''Day'</th>
339     *                  <td>'''G''''Day'''</td>
340     *              </tr>
341     *              <tr>
342     *                  <th scope="row">I'''M</th>
343     *                  <td>'I''''''M'</td>
344     *              </tr>
345     *          </tbody>
346     *      </table>
347     *  </blockquote>
348     *
349     *  @param  value A character String.
350     *  @return A string enclosed by single quotes with every single quote
351     *      converted to two single quotes
352     *  @throws NullPointerException    The {@code value} argument was
353     *      {@code null}.
354     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred.
355     */
356    public String enquoteLiteral( String value ) throws SQLException;
357
358    /**
359     *  <p>{@summary Returns a {@code String} representing a National Character
360     *  Set Literal enclosed in single quotes and prefixed with a upper case
361     *  letter {@code N}.} Any occurrence of a single quote within the string
362     *  will be replaced by two single quotes.</p>
363     *
364     *  <blockquote>
365     *    <table class="striped">
366     *      <caption>Examples of the conversion:</caption>
367     *      <thead>
368     *        <tr>
369     *          <th scope="col">Value</th>
370     *          <th scope="col">Result</th>
371     *        </tr>
372     *      </thead>
373     *      <tbody>
374     *        <tr>
375     *          <th scope="row">Hello</th>
376     *          <td>N'Hello'</td>
377     *        </tr>
378     *        <tr>
379     *          <th scope="row">G'Day</th>
380     *          <td>N'G''Day'</td>
381     *        </tr>
382     *        <tr>
383     *          <th scope="row">'G''Day'</th>
384     *          <td>N'''G''''Day'''</td>
385     *        </tr>
386     *        <tr>
387     *          <th scope="row">I'''M</th>
388     *          <td>N'I''''''M'</td>
389     *        </tr>
390     *        <tr>
391     *          <th scope="row">N'Hello'</th>
392     *          <td>N'N''Hello'''</td>
393     *        </tr>
394     *      </tbody>
395     *    </table>
396     *  </blockquote>
397     *
398     *  @param  s   A character string
399     *  @return The result of replacing every single quote character in the
400     *      argument by two single quote characters where this entire result is
401     *      then prefixed with 'N'.
402     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred.
403     *
404     *  @see java.sql.Statement#enquoteNCharLiteral(String)
405     */
406    public String enquoteNCharLiteral( String s ) throws SQLException;
407
408    /**
409     *  <p>{@summary Executes the SQL statement in this
410     *  {@code PreparedStatement} object, which may be any kind of SQL
411     *  statement.}</p>
412     *  <p>Some prepared statements return multiple results; the
413     *  {@code execute()} method handles these complex statements as well as
414     *  the simpler form of statements handled by the methods
415     *  {@link #executeQuery()}
416     *  and
417     *  {@link #executeUpdate()}.</p>
418     *  <p>The {@code execute()} method returns a {@code boolean} to indicate
419     *  the form of the first result. You must call either the method
420     *  {@link #getResultSet()}
421     *  or
422     *  {@link #getUpdateCount()}
423     *  to retrieve the result; you must call
424     *  {@link #getMoreResults()}
425     *  to move to any subsequent result(s).</p>
426     *
427     *  @return {@code true} if the first result is a
428     *      {@link ResultSet}
429     *      instance; {@code false} if the first result is an update count or
430     *      there is no result.
431     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
432     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or no
433     *      argument was supplied for at least one parameter.
434     *  @throws SQLTimeoutException The driver determined that the timeout
435     *      value that was specified by the
436     *      {@link #setQueryTimeout(int)}
437     *      method has been exceeded and has at least attempted to cancel the
438     *      currently running
439     *      {@link java.sql.Statement}.
440     *
441     *  @see    java.sql.Statement#execute
442     *  @see    #getResultSet()
443     *  @see    #getUpdateCount()
444     *  @see    #getMoreResults()
445     */
446    @SuppressWarnings( "BooleanMethodNameMustStartWithQuestion" )
447    public boolean execute() throws SQLException;
448
449    /**
450     *  <p>{@summary Submits a batch of commands to the database for execution
451     *  and if all commands execute successfully, returns an array of update
452     *  counts.} The {@code int} elements of the array that is returned are
453     *  ordered to correspond to the commands in the batch, which are ordered
454     *  according to the order in which they were added to the batch.</p>
455     *  <p>The elements in the array returned by the method
456     *  {@code executeBatch()} may be one of the following:</p>
457     *  <ol>
458     *      <li>A number greater than or equal to zero â indicates that the
459     *      command was processed successfully and is an update count giving
460     *      the number of rows in the database that were affected by the
461     *      command's execution.</li>
462     *      <li>A value of
463     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#SUCCESS_NO_INFO}
464     *      ({@value java.sql.Statement#SUCCESS_NO_INFO} â indicates that the
465     *      command was processed successfully but that the number of rows
466     *      affected is unknown.</li>
467     *  </ol>
468     *  <p>If one of the commands in a batch update fails to execute properly,
469     *  this method throws a
470     *  {@link BatchUpdateException},
471     *  and a JDBC driver may or may not continue to process the remaining
472     *  commands in the batch. However, the driver's behaviour must be
473     *  consistent with a particular DBMS, either always continuing to process
474     *  commands or never continuing to process commands. If the driver
475     *  continues processing after a failure, the array returned by the method
476     *  {@link BatchUpdateException#getUpdateCounts()}
477     *  will contain as many elements as there are commands in the batch, and
478     *  at least one of the elements will be
479     *  {@link java.sql.Statement#EXECUTE_FAILED}
480     *  ({@value java.sql.Statement#EXECUTE_FAILED} â indicating that the
481     *  command failed to execute successfully); it occurs only if a driver
482     *  continues to process commands after a command failed.</p>
483     *
484     *  @note    The possible implementations and return values have been
485     *  modified in the Java 2 SDK, Standard Edition, version 1.3 to
486     *  accommodate the option of continuing to process commands in a batch
487     *  update after a {@code BatchUpdateException} object has been thrown.
488     *
489     *  @return An array of update counts containing one element for each
490     *      command in the batch. The elements of the array are ordered
491     *      according to the order in which commands were added to the batch.
492     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
493     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
494     *      driver does not support batch statements.
495     *  @throws BatchUpdateException    One of the commands sent to the
496     *      database failed to execute properly or attempts to return a result
497     *      set.
498     *  @throws SQLTimeoutException The driver determined that the timeout
499     *      value that was specified by a call to
500     *      {@link #setQueryTimeout(int)}
501     *      was exceeded and at least attempted to cancel the currently running
502     *      statement.
503     *
504     *  @see    #addBatch()
505     *  @see    java.sql.DatabaseMetaData#supportsBatchUpdates
506     */
507    public int[] executeBatch() throws SQLException;
508
509    /**
510     *  <p>{@summary Submits a batch of commands to the database for execution
511     *  and if all commands execute successfully, returns an array of update
512     *  counts.} The {@code int} elements of the array that is returned are
513     *  ordered to correspond to the commands in the batch, which are ordered
514     *  according to the order in which they were added to the batch.</p>
515     *  <p>The elements in the array returned by the method
516     *  {@code executeBatch()} may be one of the following:</p>
517     *  <ol>
518     *      <li>A number greater than or equal to zero â indicates that the
519     *      command was processed successfully and is an update count giving
520     *      the number of rows in the database that were affected by the
521     *      command's execution.</li>
522     *      <li>A value of
523     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#SUCCESS_NO_INFO}
524     *      ({@value java.sql.Statement#SUCCESS_NO_INFO} â indicates that the
525     *      command was processed successfully but that the number of rows
526     *      affected is unknown.</li>
527     *  </ol>
528     *  <p>If one of the commands in a batch update fails to execute properly,
529     *  this method throws a
530     *  {@link BatchUpdateException},
531     *  and a JDBC driver may or may not continue to process the remaining
532     *  commands in the batch. However, the driver's behaviour must be
533     *  consistent with a particular DBMS, either always continuing to process
534     *  commands or never continuing to process commands. If the driver
535     *  continues processing after a failure, the array returned by the method
536     *  {@link BatchUpdateException#getLargeUpdateCounts()}
537     *  will contain as many elements as there are commands in the batch, and
538     *  at least one of the elements will be
539     *  {@link java.sql.Statement#EXECUTE_FAILED}
540     *  ({@value java.sql.Statement#EXECUTE_FAILED} â indicating that the
541     *  command failed to execute successfully); it occurs only if a driver
542     *  continues to process commands after a command failed.</p>
543     *  <p>This method should be used when the returned row count may exceed
544     *  {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}.</p>
545     *
546     *  @return An array of update counts containing one element for each
547     *      command in the batch. The elements of the array are ordered
548     *      according to the order in which commands were added to the batch.
549     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
550     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
551     *      driver does not support batch statements.
552     *  @throws BatchUpdateException    One of the commands sent to the
553     *      database failed to execute properly or attempts to return a result
554     *      set.
555     *  @throws SQLTimeoutException The driver determined that the timeout
556     *      value that was specified by a call to
557     *      {@link #setQueryTimeout(int)}
558     *      was exceeded and at least attempted to cancel the currently running
559     *      statement.
560     *
561     *  @see    #addBatch()
562     *  @see    #executeBatch()
563     *  @see    java.sql.Statement#executeLargeBatch()
564     *  @see    java.sql.DatabaseMetaData#supportsBatchUpdates
565     */
566    public long[] executeLargeBatch() throws SQLException;
567
568    /**
569     *  <p>{@summary Executes the SQL statement in this
570     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.} It must be an SQL Data
571     *  Manipulation Language (DML) statement, such as {@code INSERT},
572     *  {@code UPDATE} or {@code DELETE}; or an SQL statement that returns
573     *  nothing, such as a DDL statement.</p>
574     *  <p>This method should be used when the returned row count may exceed
575     *  {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}.</p>
576     *  <p>The default implementation will throw
577     *  {@link UnsupportedOperationException}.</p>
578     *
579     *  @return Either the row count for SQL Data Manipulation Language (DML)
580     *      statements or 0 for SQL statements that return nothing.
581     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
582     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the SQL
583     *      statement returns a
584     *      {@link ResultSet}
585     *      object.
586     *  @throws SQLTimeoutException The driver determined that the timeout
587     *      value that was specified by the
588     *      {@link #setQueryTimeout(int)}
589     *      method has been exceeded and has at least attempted to cancel the
590     *      currently running
591     *      {@link java.sql.Statement}.
592     */
593    public long executeLargeUpdate() throws SQLException;
594
595    /**
596     *  <p>{@summary Executes the SQL query in this {@code PreparedStatement}
597     *  object and returns the
598     *  {@link ResultSet}
599     *  object generated by the query.}</p>
600     *
601     *  @return A
602     *      {@link ResultSet}
603     *      instance that contains the data produced by the query; never
604     *      {@code null}.
605     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
606     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the SQL
607     *      statement did not return a {@code ResultSet} object.
608     *  @throws SQLTimeoutException The driver determined that the timeout
609     *      value that was specified by the
610     *      {@link #setQueryTimeout(int)}
611     *      method has been exceeded and has at least attempted to cancel the
612     *      currently running
613     *      {@link java.sql.Statement}.
614     */
615    public ResultSet executeQuery() throws SQLException;
616
617    /**
618     *  <p>{@summary Executes the SQL statement in this
619     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.} It must be an SQL Data
620     *  Manipulation Language (DML) statement, such as {@code INSERT},
621     *  {@code UPDATE} or {@code DELETE}; or an SQL statement that returns
622     *  nothing, such as a DDL statement.</p>
623     *
624     *  @return Either the row count for SQL Data Manipulation Language (DML)
625     *      statements or 0 for SQL statements that return nothing.
626     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
627     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the SQL
628     *      statement returns a
629     *      {@link ResultSet}
630     *      object.
631     *  @throws SQLTimeoutException The driver determined that the timeout
632     *      value that was specified by the
633     *      {@link #setQueryTimeout(int)}
634     *      method has been exceeded and has at least attempted to cancel the
635     *      currently running
636     *      {@link java.sql.Statement}.
637     */
638    public int executeUpdate() throws SQLException;
639
640    /**
641     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the
642     *  {@link Connection}
643     *  instance that produced the
644     *  {@link java.sql.PreparedStatement}
645     *  instance wrapped by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.}</p>
646     *
647     *  @return The connection that produced the wrapped prepared statement.
648     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
649     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
650     */
651    public Connection getConnection()  throws SQLException;
652
653    /**
654     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the direction for fetching rows from database
655     *  tables that is the default for result sets generated from this
656     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.}</p>
657     *  <p>If this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance has not set a
658     *  fetch direction by calling the method
659     *  {@link #setFetchDirection(int)},
660     *  the return value is implementation-specific.</p>
661     *
662     *  @return The default fetch direction for result sets generated from this
663     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.
664     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
665     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
666     *
667     *  @see    #setFetchDirection(int)
668     */
669    public int getFetchDirection() throws SQLException;

671    /**
672     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the number of result set rows that is the
673     *  default fetch size for
674     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
675     *  instances generated from this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
676     *  instance.} If this statement instance has not set a fetch size by
677     *  calling the method
678     *  {@link #setFetchSize(int)},
679     *  the return value is implementation-specific.</p>
680     *
681     *  @return The default fetch size for result sets generated from this
682     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.

684     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.

687     */
688    public int getFetchSize() throws SQLException;

691     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves any auto-generated keys created as a result of
692     *  executing this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.} If this
693     *  statement did not generate any keys, an empty
694     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
695     *  object is returned.</p>
696     *
697     *  @note   If the columns which represent the auto-generated keys were not
698     *      specified, the JDBC driver implementation will determine the
699     *      columns which best represent the auto-generated keys.
700     *

702     *      key(s) generated by the execution of this

707     *      support this method.

709    public ResultSet getGeneratedKeys() throws SQLException;

711    /**
712     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the maximum number of rows that a
713     *  {@link ResultSet}
714     *  instance produced by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance
715     *  can contain.} If this limit is exceeded, the excess rows are silently
716     *  dropped.</p>
717     *  <p>This method should be used when the returned row limit may exceed
718     *  {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}.</p>
719     *  <p>The default implementation will return {@code 0}.</p>
720     *
721     *  @return The current maximum number of rows for a {@code ResultSet}
722     *      instance produced by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
723     *      instance; zero means there is no limit, or that the method is not
724     *      supported by the JDBC driver.
725     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
726     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
727     *
728     *  @see    #getMaxRows()
729     *  @see    #setMaxRows(int)
730     *  @see    #setLargeMaxRows(long)
731      */
732    public long getLargeMaxRows() throws SQLException;

735     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the current result as an update count.} If the
736     *  result is a
737     *  {@link ResultSet}
738     *  object or there are no more results, -1 is returned.</p>
739     *  <p>This method should be used when the returned row count may exceed
740     *  {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}.</p>
741     *  <p>The default implementation will throw
742     *  {@link UnsupportedOperationException}</p>
743     *

745     *      is a {@code ResultSet} object or there are no more results.

747     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
748     *

750     */

753    /**
754     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the maximum number of bytes that can be
755     *  returned for character and binary column values in a
756     *  {@link ResultSet}
757     *  object produced by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} object.}</p>
758     *  <p>This limit applies only to
759     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#BINARY},
760     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#VARBINARY},
761     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGVARBINARY},
762     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#CHAR},
763     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#VARCHAR},
764     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NCHAR},
765     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NVARCHAR},
766     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGNVARCHAR}
767     *  and
768     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGVARCHAR}
769     *  columns. If the limit is exceeded, the excess data is silently
770     *  discarded.</p>
771     *
772     *  @return The current column size limit for columns storing character and
773     *      binary values; zero means there is no limit.
774     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
775     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
776     *
777     *  @see    #setMaxFieldSize(int)
778     */
779    public int getMaxFieldSize() throws SQLException;

786     *  dropped.</p>

789     *      instance produced by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}

792     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.

796     *  @see    #setLargeMaxRows(long)

800    /**
801     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves a
802     *  {@link ResultSetMetaData}
803     *  object that contains information about the columns of the
804     *  {@link ResultSet}
805     *  instance that will be returned when this
806     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
807     *  instance is executed.}</p>
808     *  <p>Because the
809     *  {@link java.sql.PreparedStatement}
810     *  that is wrapped by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} is
811     *  precompiled, it is possible to know about the {@code ResultSet} object
812     *  that it will return without having to execute it. Consequently, it is
813     *  possible to invoke the method {@code getMetaData()} on a
814     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance rather than waiting to
815     *  execute it and then invoking the
816     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet#getMetaData()}
817     *  method on the {@code ResultSet} instance that is returned.</p>
818     *
819     *  @note   Using this method may be expensive for some drivers due to the
820     *      lack of underlying DBMS support.
821     *
822     *  @return The description of a {@code ResultSet} object's columns or
823     *      {@code null} if the driver cannot return a
824     *      {@code ResultSetMetaData} object.
825     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
826     *      was called on a closed {@code PreparedStatement}.
827     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
828     *      support this method.
829     */
830    public ResultSetMetaData getMetaData() throws SQLException;
831
832    /**
833     *  <p>{@summary Moves to this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance's
834     *  next result, returns {@code true} if it is a
835     *  {@link ResultSet}
836     *  instance, and implicitly closes any current {@code ResultSet}
837     *  instance(s) previously obtained with the method
838     *  {@link #getResultSet()}.}</p>
839     *  <p>There are no more results when the following is true:</p>
840     *  <pre><code>
841     *     // stmt is a EnhancedPreparedStatement object
842     *     ((stmt.getMoreResults() == false) &amp;&amp; (stmt.getUpdateCount() == -1))
843     *  </code></pre>
844     *
845     *  @return {@code true} if the next result is a {@code ResultSet}
846     *      instance; {@code false} if it is an update count or there are no
847     *      more results.
848     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
849     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
850     *
851     *  @see    #execute()
852     */
853    @SuppressWarnings( "BooleanMethodNameMustStartWithQuestion" )
854    public boolean getMoreResults() throws SQLException;
855
856    /**
857     *  <p>{@summary Moves to this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance's
858     *  next result, deals with any current
859     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
860     *  instance(s) according  to the instructions specified by the given flag,
861     *  and returns {@code true} if the next result is a {@code ResultSet}
862     *  object.}</p>
863     *  <p>There are no more results when the following is true:</p>
864     *  <pre><code>
865     *     // stmt is a Statement object
866     *     ((stmt.getMoreResults(&nbsp;current&nbsp;) == false) &amp;&amp; (stmt.getUpdateCount() == -1))
867     *  </code></pre>
868     *
869     *  @param  current One of the following {@code Statement} constants
870     *      indicating what should happen to current
871     *      {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
872     *      instances obtained using the method
873     *      {@link #getResultSet()}:
874     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#CLOSE_CURRENT_RESULT},
875     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#KEEP_CURRENT_RESULT},
876     *      or
877     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#CLOSE_ALL_RESULTS}.
878     *  @return {@code true} if the next result is a {@code ResultSet}
879     *      instance, {@code false} if it is an update count or there are no
880     *      more results
881     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
882     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
883     *      argument supplied is not one of the following:
884     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#CLOSE_CURRENT_RESULT},
885     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#KEEP_CURRENT_RESULT},
886     *      or
887     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#CLOSE_ALL_RESULTS}.
888     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException
889     *      {@link java.sql.DatabaseMetaData#supportsMultipleOpenResults()}
890     *      returned {@code false} and either
891     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#KEEP_CURRENT_RESULT}
892     *      or
893     *      {@link java.sql.Statement#CLOSE_ALL_RESULTS}
894     *      are supplied as the argument.
895     *
896     *  @see    #execute()
897     *  @see    #getMoreResults()
898     */
899    @SuppressWarnings( "BooleanMethodNameMustStartWithQuestion" )
900    public boolean getMoreResults( final int current ) throws SQLException;
901

1015    /**
1016     *  <p>{@summary Retrieves the first warning reported by calls on this
1017     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance.} Subsequent warnings
1018     *  regarding the execution of this instance will be chained to this
1019     *  {@link java.sql.SQLWarning}
1020     *  instance</p>.
1021     *  <p>The warning chain is automatically cleared each time a statement is
1022     *  (re)executed. This method may not be called on a closed
1023     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance; doing so will cause an
1024     *  {@link SQLException}
1025     *  to be thrown.</p>
1026     *
1027     *  @note   If you are processing a {@code ResultSet} instance, any
1028     *      warnings associated with reads on that {@code ResultSet} instance
1029     *      will be chained on it rather than on the statement instance that
1030     *      produced it.
1031     *
1032     *  @return The first {@code SQLWarning} object or {@code null} if there
1033     *      are no warnings.
1034     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
1035     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1036     *
1037     *  @see    #clearWarnings()
1038     */
1039    public SQLWarning getWarnings() throws SQLException;

1043     *  object has been closed.} An {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} is closed
1044     *  if the method
1045     *  {@link #close()} has been called on it, or if it is automatically
1046     *  closed.</p>
1047     *
1048     *  @return {@code true} if this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} object
1049     *      is closed; {@code false} if it is still open.
1050     *
1051     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred.
1052     */
1053    public boolean isClosed() throws SQLException;

1057     *  {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} will be closed when all its dependent
1058     *  result sets are closed.}</p>
1059     *
1060     *  @return {@code true} if this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} will be
1061     *      closed when all of its dependent result sets are closed,
1062     *      {@code false} otherwise.
1063     *
1064     *  @throws SQLException    This method was called on a closed
1065     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1066     */
1067    public boolean isCloseOnCompletion() throws SQLException;

1095     *  @return {@code true} if the given value is a simple SQL identifier,
1096     *      {@code false} otherwise
1097     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred.
1098     */
1099    public boolean isSimpleIdentifier( final String identifier) throws SQLException;
1100
1101    /**
1102     *  <p>{@summary Creates a new {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
1103     *  instance.}</p>
1104     *  <p>The text for the SQL statement is different from the format that
1105     *  is used by
1106     *  {@link java.sql.Connection#prepareStatement(String)}
1107     *  to create an instance of
1108     *  {@link java.sql.PreparedStatement}:
1109     *  this format uses explicit names instead of simple question marks as
1110     *  placeholders. This means, instead of</p>
1111     *  <pre><code>SELECT value FROM table WHERE key = ?</code></pre>
1112     *  <p>one will write</p>
1113     *  <pre><code>SELECT value FROM table WHERE key = :key</code></pre>
1114     *  <p>This allows to address the variables by name, and it makes it
1115     *  possible that the same value is only provided once, despite it occurs
1116     *  multiple time.</p>
1117     *  <p>A parameter name is prefixed by a colon, followed by an ASCII
1118     *  letter, then by an arbitrary number of ASCII letters and digits. No
1119     *  special characters are allowed.</p>
1120     *
1121     *  @param  connection  The connection to the database.
1122     *  @param  sql The text of the SQL statement with the placeholders.
1123     *  @return The new statement.
1124     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, or the given
1125     *      statement could not be parsed properly.
1126     */
1127    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.1.0" )
1128    public static EnhancedPreparedStatement prepareStatement( final Connection connection, final String sql ) throws SQLException
1129    {
1130        final EnhancedPreparedStatement retValue = EnhancedPreparedStatementImpl.create( connection, sql );
1131
1132        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
1133        return retValue;
1134    }   //  prepareStatement()

1154    /**
1155     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
1156     *  {@link java.io.InputStream}
1157     *  which will have the specified number of bytes.}</p>
1158     *  <p>When a very large ASCII value is input to a {@code LONGVARCHAR}
1159     *  parameter, it may be more practical to send it via a
1160     *  {@code java.io.InputStream}. The data will be read from the stream as
1161     *  needed until end-of-file is reached. The JDBC driver will do any
1162     *  necessary conversion from ASCII to the database char format.</p>
1163     *
1164     *  @note   This stream object can either be a standard Java stream object
1165     *      or your own subclass that implements the standard interface.
1166     *
1167     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1168     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
1169     *  @param  length  The number of bytes in the stream.
1170     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1171     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1172     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
1173     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1174     */
1175    public void setAsciiStream( final String parameterName, final InputStream value, final int length ) throws SQLException;

1329    /**
1330     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to a
1331     *  {@link java.io.InputStream}
1332     *  object.} The {@code InputStream} must contain  the number of characters
1333     *  as specified by the {@code length} argument, otherwise a
1334     *  {@link SQLException}
1335     *  will be generated when the {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} is
1336     *  executed.</p>
1337     *  <p>This method differs from the
1338     *  {@link #setBinaryStream (String,InputStream,int)}
1339     *  method because it informs the driver that the parameter value should be
1340     *  sent to the server as a {@code BLOB}. When the
1341     *  {@code setBinaryStream()} method is used, the driver may have to do
1342     *  extra work to determine whether the parameter data should be sent to
1343     *  the server as a {@code LONGVARBINARY} or a {@code BLOB}.</p>
1344     *
1345     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1346     *  @param  value   The {@code InputStream} instance that contains the data
1347     *      to set the parameter value to.
1348     *  @param  length  The number of bytes in the parameter data.
1349     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1350     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1351     *      occurred, this method was called on a closed
1352     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}, the specified length was less
1353     *      than zero or if the number of bytes in the {@code InputStream} did
1354     *      not match the specified length.
1355     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
1356     *      support this method.
1357     */
1358    public void setBlob(  final String parameterName, final InputStream value, final long length ) throws SQLException;

1369     *  extra work to determine whether the parameter data should be sent to

1583    /**
1584     *  <p>{@summary Sets the SQL cursor name to the given String, which will
1585     *  be used by subsequent statement {@code execute()} methods.} This name
1586     *  can then be used in SQL positioned update or delete statements to
1587     *  identify the current row in the
1588     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
1589     *  instance generated by this statement.  If the database does not support
1590     *  positioned update/delete, this method is a noop.  To ensure that a
1591     *  cursor has the proper isolation level to support updates, the cursor's
1592     *  {@code SELECT} statement should have the form
1593     *  {@code SELECT FOR UPDATE}. If {@code FOR UPDATE} is not present,
1594     *  positioned updates may fail.</p>
1595     *
1596     *  @note   By definition, the execution of positioned updates and deletes
1597     *  must be done by a different statement instances than the one that
1598     *  generated the {@code ResultSet} object being used for positioning.
1599     *  Also, cursor names must be unique within a connection.
1600     *
1601     *  @param  name    The new cursor name, which must be unique within a
1602     *      connection.
1603     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred or this method
1604     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1605     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
1606     *      support this method.
1607     */
1608    public void setCursorName( final String name ) throws SQLException;
1609
1610    /**
1611     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
1612     *  {@link java.sql.Date}
1613     *  value using the default time zone of the virtual machine that is
1614     *  running the application.}</p>
1615     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code DATE} value when it
1616     *  sends it to the database.</p>
1617     *
1618     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1619     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
1620     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1621     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1622     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
1623     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1624     */
1625    public void setDate( final String parameterName, final Date value ) throws SQLException;
1626
1627    /**
1628     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
1629     *  {@link java.sql.Date}
1630     *  value using the given
1631     *  {@link java.util.Calendar}
1632     *  instance.} The driver used the {@code Calendar} instance to construct
1633     *  an SQL {@code DATE} value, which the driver then sends to the database.
1634     *  With the {@code Calendar} instance, the driver can calculate the date
1635     *  taking into account a custom timezone. If no {@code Calendar} instance
1636     *  is specified, the driver uses the default timezone, which is that of
1637     *  the virtual machine running the application.</p>
1638     *
1639     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1640     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
1641     *  @param  calendar    The {@code Calendar} instance the driver will use
1642     *      to construct the date.
1643     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1644     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1645     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
1646     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1647     */
1648    @SuppressWarnings( "UseOfObsoleteDateTimeApi" )
1649    public void setDate( final String parameterName, final Date value, final Calendar calendar ) throws SQLException;
1650
1651    /**
1652     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given Java
1653     *  {@code double} value.}</p>
1654     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code DOUBLE} value when it
1655     *  sends it to the database.</p>
1656     *
1657     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1658     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
1659     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1660     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1661     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
1662     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1663     */
1664    public void setDouble( final String parameterName, final double value ) throws SQLException;
1665
1666    /**
1667     *  <p>{@summary Gives the driver a hint as to the direction in which rows
1668     *  will be processed in
1669     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
1670     *  instances created using this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} object.}
1671     *  The default value is
1672     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet#FETCH_FORWARD}.</p>
1673     *  <p>Note that this method sets only the default fetch direction for
1674     *  result sets generated by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
1675     *  instance. Each result set has its own methods for getting and setting
1676     *  its own fetch direction.</p>
1677     *
1678     *  @param  direction   The initial direction for processing rows.
1679     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
1680     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
1681     *      given direction is not one of
1682     *      {@link java.sql.ResultSet#FETCH_FORWARD},
1683     *      {@link java.sql.ResultSet#FETCH_REVERSE},
1684     *      or
1685     *      {@link java.sql.ResultSet#FETCH_UNKNOWN}
1686     *
1687     *  @see    #getFetchDirection()
1688     *  @see    java.sql.ResultSet#setFetchDirection(int)
1689     *  @see    java.sql.ResultSet#getFetchDirection()
1690     */
1691    public void setFetchDirection( final int direction ) throws SQLException;
1692
1693    /**
1694     *  <p>{@summary Gives the JDBC driver a hint as to the number of rows that
1695     *  should be fetched from the database when more rows are needed for
1696     *  {@link java.sql.ResultSet}
1697     *  instances generated by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}
1698     *  instance.}
1699     *  If the specified value is zero, then the hint is ignored.</p>
1700     *  <p>The default value is zero.</p>
1701     *
1702     *  @param  rows    The number of rows to fetch.
1703     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
1704     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
1705     *      condition {@code rows >= 0} was not satisfied.
1706     */
1707    public void setFetchSize( final int rows ) throws SQLException;

1741     *  {@link ResultSet}
1742     *  instance generated by this {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} instance
1743     *  can contain.} If the limit is exceeded, the excess rows are silently
1744     *  dropped.</p>
1745     *  <p>This method should be used when the row limit may exceed
1746     *  {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}.</p>

1748     *  {@link UnsupportedOperationException}.</p>

1752     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
1753     *      condition {@code max >= 0} is not satisfied.
1754     *
1755     *  @see    #setMaxRows(int)
1756     *  @see    #getMaxRows()
1757     *  @see    #getLargeMaxRows()
1758     */
1759    public void setLargeMaxRows( final long max) throws SQLException;

1776    /**
1777     *  <p>{@summary Sets the limit for the maximum number of bytes that can be
1778     *  returned for character and binary column values in a {@code ResultSet}
1779     *  object produced by this {@code Statement} object.}</p>
1780     *  <p>This limit applies only to
1781     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#BINARY},
1782     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#VARBINARY},
1783     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGVARBINARY},
1784     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#CHAR},
1785     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#VARCHAR},
1786     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NCHAR},
1787     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NVARCHAR},
1788     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGNVARCHAR}
1789     *  and
1790     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGVARCHAR}
1791     *  columns. If the limit is exceeded, the excess data is silently
1792     *  discarded. For maximum portability, use values greater than 256.</p>
1793     *
1794     *  @param  max The new column size limit in bytes; zero means there is no
1795     *      limit.
1796     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
1797     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
1798     *      condition {@code max >= 0} is not satisfied.
1799     *
1800     *  @see    #getMaxFieldSize()
1801     */
1802    public void setMaxFieldSize( final int max ) throws SQLException;

1809     *  rows are silently dropped.</p>

1820    public void setMaxRows( final int max ) throws SQLException;

1824     *  {@link Reader}
1825     *  instance.}</p>

1827     *  driver does the necessary conversion from Java character format to the
1828     *  national character set in the database.</p>
1829     *

1832     *      data.

1834     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1835     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, the driver does not support
1836     *      national character sets, the driver detected that a data conversion
1837     *      error could occur, a database access error occurred or this method
1838     *      was called on a closed
1839     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1840     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
1841     *      support this method,
1842     */
1843    void setNCharacterStream(  final String parameterName, final Reader value, long length) throws SQLException;

1845    /**
1846     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
1847     *  {@link Reader}
1848     *  instance.}</p>
1849     *  <p>The {@code Reader} reads the data till end-of-file is reached. The
1850     *  driver does the necessary conversion from Java character format to the
1851     *  national character set in the database.</p>
1852     *
1853     *  @note   This reader object can either be a standard Java {@code Reader}
1854     *      object or your own subclass that implements the standard interface.
1855     *  @note   Consult your JDBC driver documentation to determine if it might
1856     *      be more efficient to use a version of {@code setNCharacterStream()}
1857     *      which takes a length parameter.
1858     *
1859     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1860     *  @param  value   The {@code java.io.Reader} object that contains the
1861     *      data.
1862     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1863     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, the driver does not support
1864     *      national character sets, the driver detected that a data conversion
1865     *      error could occur, a database access error occurred or this method
1866     *      was called on a closed
1867     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1868     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
1869     *      support this method,
1870     */
1871    public void setNCharacterStream( final String parameterName, final Reader value) throws SQLException;

1875     *  {@link java.sql.NClob} value.}</p>

1877     *  sends it to the database.</p>
1878     *

1883     *      national character sets, the driver detected that a data conversion
1884     *      error could occur, a database access error occurred or this method

1890    public void setNClob( final String parameterName, final NClob value ) throws SQLException;

1892    /**
1893     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to a
1894     *  {@link java.io.Reader}
1895     *  instance.} The reader must contain the number of characters specified
1896     *  by the {@code length} argument, otherwise a
1897     *  {@link SQLException}
1898     *  will be generated when the {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} is
1899     *  executed.</p>
1900     *  <p>This method differs from the
1901     *  {@link #setNCharacterStream(String,Reader,long)}
1902     *  method because it informs the driver that the parameter value should be
1903     *  sent to the server as a {@code NCLOB}. When the
1904     *  {@code setNCharacterStream()} method is used, the driver may have to do
1905     *  extra work to determine whether the parameter data should be sent to
1906     *  the server as a {@code LONGNVARCHAR} or a {@code NCLOB}.</p>
1907     *
1908     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1909     *  @param  value   The {@code java.io.Reader} object that contains the
1910     *      data to set the parameter value to.
1911     *  @param  length The number of characters in the stream.
1912     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1913     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1914     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
1915     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}, the {@code Reader} was shorter
1916     *      than specified, or the specified length was less than zero.
1917     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException  The JDBC driver does not
1918     *      support this method.
1919     */
1920    public void setNClob( final String parameterName, final Reader value, final long length ) throws SQLException;
1921
1922    /**
1923     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to a
1924     *  {@link java.io.Reader}
1925     *  instance.}</p>
1926     *  <p>This method differs from the
1927     *  {@link #setNCharacterStream(String,Reader,long)}
1928     *  method because it informs the driver that the parameter value should be
1929     *  sent to the server as a {@code NCLOB}. When the
1930     *  {@code setNCharacterStream()} method is used, the driver may have to do
1931     *  extra work to determine whether the parameter data should be sent to
1932     *  the server as a {@code LONGNVARCHAR} or a {@code NCLOB}.</p>
1933     *
1934     *  @note   Consult your JDBC driver documentation to determine if it might
1935     *      be more efficient to use a version of {@code setNClob()} which
1936     *      takes a length parameter.
1937     *
1938     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1939     *  @param  value   The {@code java.io.Reader} object that contains the
1940     *      data to set the parameter value to.

1946     *      support this method.

1950    /**
1951     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given Java
1952     *  {@link String} value.}</p>
1953     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code NCHAR}, {@code NVARCHAR},
1954     *  or {@code LONGNVARCHAR} value (depending on the argument's size
1955     *  relative to the driver's limits on {@code NVARCHAR} values)when it
1956     *  sends it to the database.</p>
1957     *  <p>For the logging, it is always {@code NCHAR}.</p>

1963     *      support national character sets, the driver detected that a data
1964     *      conversion error could occur, a database access error occurred or
1965     *      this method was called on a closed
1966     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1967     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
1968     *      support this method.
1969     */
1970    public void setNString( final String parameterName, final String value ) throws SQLException;
