1972    /**
1973     *  Sets the designated parameter to SQL {@code NULL}.
1974     *
1975     *  @note   You must specify the parameter's SQL type.
1976     *
1977     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
1978     *  @param  sqlType The SQL type code.
1979     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
1980     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
1981     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
1982     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
1983     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The {@code sqlType} is a
1984     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#ARRAY},
1985     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#BLOB},
1986     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#CLOB},
1987     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#DATALINK},
1988     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#JAVA_OBJECT},
1989     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NCHAR},
1990     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NCLOB},
1991     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NVARCHAR},
1992     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGNVARCHAR},
1993     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#REF},
1994     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#ROWID},
1995     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#SQLXML}
1996     *      or
1997     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#STRUCT}
1998     *      data type and the JDBC driver does not support this data type.
1999     *
2000     *  @see    java.sql.JDBCType
2001     */
2002    public void setNull( final String parameterName, final SQLType sqlType ) throws SQLException;
2003
2004    /**
2005     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to SQL {@code NULL}.}</p>
2006     *  <p>This version of the method {@code setNull()} should be used for
2007     *  user-defined types and REF type parameters. Examples of user-defined
2008     *  types include: {@code STRUCT}, {@code DISTINCT}, {@code JAVA_OBJECT},
2009     *  and named array types.</p>
2010     *  <p>Although this method is intended for user-defined and {@code REF}
2011     *  parameters, this method may be used to set a {@code null} parameter of
2012     *  any JDBC type. If the parameter does not have a user-defined or
2013     *  {@code REF} type, the given {@code typeName} is ignored.</p>
2014     *
2015     *  @note   To be portable, applications must give the SQL type code and
2016     *      the fully-qualified SQL type name when specifying a {@code NULL}
2017     *      user-defined or {@code REF} parameter. In the case of a
2018     *      user-defined type the name is the type name of the parameter
2019     *      itself. For a {@code REF} parameter, the name is the type name of
2020     *      the referenced type. If a JDBC driver does not need the type code
2021     *      or type name information, it may ignore it.
2022     *
2023     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2024     *  @param  sqlType The SQL type code.
2025     *  @param typeName The fully-qualified name of an SQL user-defined type;
2026     *      ignored if the parameter is not a user-defined type or {@code REF}.
2027     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2028     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2029     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2030     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2031     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The {@code sqlType} is a
2032     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#ARRAY},
2033     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#BLOB},
2034     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#CLOB},
2035     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#DATALINK},
2036     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#JAVA_OBJECT},
2037     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NCHAR},
2038     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NCLOB},
2039     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NVARCHAR},
2040     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#LONGNVARCHAR},
2041     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#REF},
2042     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#ROWID},
2043     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#SQLXML}
2044     *      or
2045     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#STRUCT}
2046     *      data type and the JDBC driver does not support this data type.
2047     */
2048    public void setNull ( final String parameterName, final SQLType sqlType, final String typeName ) throws SQLException;
2049
2050    /**
2051     *  <p>{@summary Sets the value of the designated parameter using the given
2052     *  object.}</p>
2053     *  <p>The JDBC specification specifies a standard mapping from Java
2054     *  {@code Object} types to SQL types.  The given argument will be
2055     *  converted to the corresponding SQL type before being sent to the
2056     *  database.</p>
2057     *  <p>Note that this method may be used to pass database- specific
2058     *  abstract data types, by using a driver-specific Java type.</p>
2059     *  <p>If the object is of a class implementing the interface
2060     *  {@link java.sql.SQLData},
2061     *  the JDBC driver should call the method {@code SQLData.writeSQL} to
2062     *  write it to the SQL data stream.</p>
2063     *  <p>If, on the other hand, the object is of a class implementing
2064     *  {@link java.sql.Ref},
2065     *  {@link java.sql.Blob},
2066     *  {@link java.sql.Clob},
2067     *  {@link java.sql.NClob},
2068     *  {@link java.sql.Struct},
2069     *  {@link java.net.URL},
2070     *  {@link java.sql.RowId},
2071     *  {@link java.sql.SQLXML}
2072     *  or
2073     *  {@link java.sql.Array},
2074     *  the driver should pass it to the database as a value of the
2075     *  corresponding SQL type.</p>
2076     *
2077     *  @note   Not all databases allow for a non-typed {@code NULL} to be sent
2078     *  to the backend. For maximum portability, the {@code setNull()} or the
2079     *  {@code setObject( final String parameterName, final Object x, int sqlType )}
2080     *  method should be used instead of {@code setObject( final String parameterName, final Object value )}
2081     *  with {@code value} set to {@code null}
2082     *
2083     *  @note   This method throws an exception if there is an ambiguity, for
2084     *      example, if the object is of a class implementing more than one of
2085     *      the interfaces named above.
2086     *
2087     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2088     *  @param  value   The object containing the input parameter value.
2089     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2090     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2091     *      occurred, this method was called on a closed
2092     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the type of the given object
2093     *      is ambiguous.
2094     */
2095    public void setObject( final String parameterName, final Object value ) throws SQLException;
2096
2097    /**
2098     *  <p>{@summary Sets the value of the designated parameter using the given
2099     *  object.}</p>
2100     *  <p>If the second argument is an
2101     *  {@link InputStream}
2102     *  or a
2103     *  {@link Reader}
2104     *  then the stream must contain the number of bytes specified by
2105     *  the {@code scaleOrLength} argument</p>.
2106     *  <p>If these conditions are not true the driver will generate a
2107     *  {@link SQLException}
2108     *  when the prepared statement is executed.</p>
2109     *  <p>The given Java object will be converted to the given
2110     *  {@code targetSqlType} before being sent to the database.</p>
2111     *  <p>If the object has a custom mapping (is of a class implementing the
2112     *  interface
2113     *  {@link java.sql.SQLData}),
2114     *  the JDBC driver should call the method
2115     *  {@link java.sql.SQLData#writeSQL(SQLOutput)}
2116     *  to write it to the SQL data stream.</p>
2117     *  <p>If, on the other hand, the object is of a class implementing
2118     *  {@link java.sql.Ref},
2119     *  {@link java.sql.Blob},
2120     *  {@link java.sql.Clob},
2121     *  {@link java.sql.NClob},
2122     *  {@link java.sql.Struct},
2123     *  {@link java.net.URL},
2124     *  or
2125     *  {@link java.sql.Array},
2126     *  the driver should pass it to the database as a value of the
2127     *  corresponding SQL type.</p>
2128     *  <p>Note that this method may be used to pass database-specific abstract
2129     *  data types.</p>
2130     *
2131     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2132     *  @param  value   The object containing the input parameter value.
2133     *  @param  targetSqlType   The SQL type to be sent to the database. The
2134     *      scale argument may further qualify this type.
2135     *  @param  scaleOrLength   For
2136     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#DECIMAL}
2137     *      or
2138     *      {@link java.sql.JDBCType#NUMERIC}
2139     *      types, this is the number of digits after the decimal point. For
2140     *      Java Object types
2141     *      {@link InputStream}
2142     *      and
2143     *      {@link Reader},
2144     *      this is the length of the data in the stream or reader. For all
2145     *      other types, this value will be ignored.
2146     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2147     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2148     *      occurred, this method was called on a closed
2149     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the Java Object specified by
2150     *      {@code value} is an {@code InputStream} or {@code Reader} instance
2151     *      and the value of the scale parameter is less than zero.
2152     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
2153     *      support the specified {@code targetSqlType}.
2154     *
2155     *  @see    JDBCType
2156     *  @see    SQLType
2157     */
2158    public void setObject( final String parameterName, final Object value, SQLType targetSqlType, int scaleOrLength) throws SQLException;
2159
2160    /**
2161     *  <p>{@summary Sets the value of the designated parameter with the given
2162     *  object.}</p>
2163     *  <p>This method is similar to
2164     *  {@link #setObject(String,Object,SQLType,int)},
2165     *  except that it assumes a scale of zero.</p>
2166     *
2167     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2168     *  @param  value   The object containing the input parameter value.
2169     *  @param  targetSqlType   The SQL type to be sent to the database. The
2170     *      scale argument may further qualify this type.
2171     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2172     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2173     *      occurred, or this method was called on a closed
2174     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2175     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
2176     *      support the specified {@code targetSqlType}.
2177     *
2178     *  @see    JDBCType
2179     *  @see    SQLType
2180     */
2181    public void setObject( final String parameterName, final Object value, SQLType targetSqlType ) throws SQLException;
2182
2183    /**
2184     *  <p>{@summary Sets the number of seconds the driver will wait for a
2185     *  {@link java.sql.Statement}
2186     *  instance to execute to the given number of seconds.} By default there
2187     *  is no limit on the amount of time allowed for a running statement to
2188     *  complete.</p>
2189     *  <p>If the limit is exceeded, an
2190     *  {@link SQLTimeoutException}
2191     *  is thrown.</p>
2192     *  <p>A JDBC driver must apply this limit to the
2193     *  {@link java.sql.Statement#execute(String)},
2194     *  {@link java.sql.Statement#executeQuery(String)}
2195     *  and
2196     *  {@link java.sql.Statement#executeUpdate(String)}
2197     *  methods.</p>
2198     *
2199     *  @note   JDBC driver implementations may also apply this limit to
2200     *      {@code ResultSet} methods (consult your driver vendor documentation
2201     *      for details).
2202     *
2203     *  @note   In the case of {@code Statement} batching, it is implementation
2204     *      defined whether the time-out is applied to individual SQL commands
2205     *      added via the {@code #addBatch()} method or to the entire batch of
2206     *      SQL commands invoked by the {@code executeBatch()} method (consult
2207     *      your driver vendor documentation for details).
2208     *
2209     *  @param  timeout The new query timeout limit in seconds; zero means
2210     *      there is no limit
2211     *  @throws SQLException    A database access error occurred, this method
2212     *      was called on a closed {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement} or the
2213     *      condition {@code seconds >= 0} is not satisfied
2214     *
2215     *  @see    #getQueryTimeout()
2216     */
2217    public void setQueryTimeout( final int timeout ) throws SQLException;
2218
2219    /**
2220     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2221     *  {@link java.sql.JDBCType#REF REF(&lt;structured-type&gt;)}
2222     *  value.}</p>
2223     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code REF} value when it
2224     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2225     *
2226     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2227     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2228     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2229     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2230     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2231     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2232     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
2233     *      support this method.
2234     */
2235    public void setRef ( final String parameterName, final Ref value ) throws SQLException;
2236
2237    /**
2238     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2239     *  {@link java.sql.RowId}
2240     *  instance.}</p>
2241     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code ROWID} value when it
2242     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2243     *
2244     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2245     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2246     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2247     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2248     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2249     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2250     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
2251     *      support this method.
2252     */
2253    public void setRowId( final String parameterName, final RowId value ) throws SQLException;
2254
2255    /**
2256     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given Java
2257     *  {@code short} value.}</p>
2258     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code SMALLINT} value when it
2259     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2260     *
2261     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2262     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2263     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2264     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2265     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2266     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2267     */
2268    public void setShort( final String parameterName, final short value ) throws SQLException;
2269
2270    /**
2271     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2272     *  {@link java.sql.SQLXML} value.}</p>
2273     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code SQLXML} value when it
2274     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2275     *
2276     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2277     *  @param  value   An {@code SQLXML} instance that maps an SQL
2278     *      {@code SQLXML} value.
2279     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2280     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2281     *      occurred, this method was called on a closed
2282     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}, or the
2283     *      {@link javax.xml.transform.Result},
2284     *      {@link java.io.Writer}
2285     *      or
2286     *      {@link java.io.OutputStream}
2287     *      was closed for the {@code SQLXML} object.
2288     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
2289     *      support this method.
2290     */
2291    void setSQLXML( final String parameterName, final SQLXML value ) throws SQLException;
2292
2293    /**
2294     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given Java
2295     *  {@link java.lang.String}
2296     *  value.}</p>
2297     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code VARCHAR} or
2298     *  {@code LONGVARCHAR} value (depending on the argument's size relative to the
2299     *  driver's limits on {@code VARCHAR} values) when it sends it to the
2300     *  database.</p>
2301     *  <p>For the logging, it is always {@code VARCHAR}.</p>
2302     *
2303     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2304     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2305     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2306     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2307     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2308     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2309     */
2310    public void setString( final String parameterName, final String value ) throws SQLException;
2311
2312    /**
2313     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2314     *  {@link java.sql.Time}
2315     *  value.}</p>
2316     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code TIME} value when it
2317     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2318     *
2319     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2320     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2321     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2322     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2323     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2324     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2325     */
2326    public void setTime( final String parameterName, final Time value ) throws SQLException;
2327
2328    /**
2329     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2330     *  {@link java.sql.Time}
2331     *  value using the given
2332     *  {@link java.util.Calendar}
2333     *  instance.} The driver used the {@code Calendar} instance to construct
2334     *  an SQL {@code TIME} value, which the driver then sends to the database.
2335     *  With the {@code Calendar} instance, the driver can calculate the date
2336     *  taking into account a custom timezone. If no {@code Calendar} instance
2337     *  is specified, the driver uses the default timezone, which is that of
2338     *  the virtual machine running the application.</p>
2339     *
2340     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2341     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2342     *  @param  calendar    The {@code Calendar} instance the driver will use
2343     *      to construct the date.
2344     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2345     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2346     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2347     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2348     */
2349    @SuppressWarnings( "UseOfObsoleteDateTimeApi" )
2350    public void setTime( final String parameterName, final Time value, final Calendar calendar ) throws SQLException;
2351
2352    /**
2353     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2354     *  {@link java.sql.Timestamp}
2355     *  value.}</p>
2356     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code TIMESTAMP} value when it
2357     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2358     *
2359     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2360     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2361     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2362     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2363     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2364     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2365     */
2366    public void setTimestamp( final String parameterName, final Timestamp value ) throws SQLException;
2367
2368    /**
2369     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2370     *  {@link java.sql.Timestamp}
2371     *  value using the given
2372     *  {@link java.util.Calendar}
2373     *  instance.} The driver used the {@code Calendar} instance to construct
2374     *  an SQL {@code TIMESTAMP} value, which the driver then sends to the
2375     *  database. With the {@code Calendar} instance, the driver can calculate
2376     *  the timestamp taking into account a custom timezone. If no
2377     *  {@code Calendar} instance is specified, the driver uses the default
2378     *  timezone, which is that of the virtual machine running the
2379     *  application.</p>
2380     *
2381     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2382     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2383     *  @param  calendar    The {@code Calendar} instance the driver will use
2384     *      to construct the date.
2385     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2386     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2387     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2388     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2389     */
2390    @SuppressWarnings( "UseOfObsoleteDateTimeApi" )
2391    public void setTimestamp( final String parameterName, final Timestamp value, final Calendar calendar ) throws SQLException;
2392
2393    /**
2394     *  <p>{@summary Sets the designated parameter to the given
2395     *  {@link java.net.URL}
2396     *  value.}</p>
2397     *  <p>The driver converts this to an SQL {@code DATALINK} value when it
2398     *  sends it to the database.</p>
2399     *
2400     *  @param  parameterName   The name of the parameter, prefixed by a colon.
2401     *  @param  value   The parameter value.
2402     *  @throws SQLException    The parameter name did not correspond to any
2403     *      defined parameter in the SQL statement, a database access error
2404     *      occurred or this method was called on a closed
2405     *      {@code EnhancedPreparedStatement}.
2406     *  @throws SQLFeatureNotSupportedException The JDBC driver does not
2407     *      support this method.
2408     */
2409    public void setURL( final String parameterName, final URL value ) throws SQLException;
